title: Will France grant the China Global Television Network (CGTN) a license to broadcast in France before 1 January 2022?

Interesting, how words complicate this matter:
DW reported on 06 March 2021, that CGTN received "permission" by the French CSA (with the consequence of being received e.g. in the German Vodafone network), in line with the "1989 transfrontier television agreement".
However, DW delivers the same interpretation that "CGTN's managers approached the Conseil Supérieur de l'Audiovisuel (CSA) for confirmation that this service was now under French jurisdiction under European law," the CSA said in a statement published on its website." and further:
"a distribution license in one European country is valid across the continent, German media authorities had to notify television networks, such as Vodafone, that the CGTN channel no longer had permission to broadcast." " 'The CSA confirmed this interpretation [about French jurisdiction] ,' it added." But nothing more so far.
https://www.dw.com/en/chinas-cgtn-returns-to-german-tv-screens/a-56794408 It may well be that licensing TV applies to the terrestrial TV stations system TNT ("Télévision Numérique Terrestre") that uses DVB-T for broadcasting and which currently offers 27 TV stations, and which has a large overlap with the public French broadcasting stations that receive licence fees collected from viewers with their taxes.

I think this question is kind of underspecified. @SE_Meyer notes there is cable and satellite broadcasting. And license could mean mere permission or some formal official document. Crucially, however:
https://www.reuters.com/article/china-france-cgtn/chinas-state-broadcaster-applies-to-france-for-right-to-air-in-europe-ft-idUSFWN2KP1N7
The original Financial Times piece says that, as per the Council of Europe treaty, if CGTN falls under the jurisdiction of at least one Council of Europe member, in this case France with the CSA, then CGTN can broadcast into the territories of all members (apparently I'm not allowed to copy the exact text according to the FT website - so have a look yourself if possible). This seems to be the crucial point that prompted this question. The announcement by the CSA has confirmed CGTN broadcasting to be under the jurisdiction of France, under the Financial Times view, it should now be able to broadcast into Council of Europe territories.  On the other hand, the details of this question says the "Financial Times has reported that CGTN approached French regulators in December 2020 about seeking a license to broadcast in France, which could return CGTN to the UK and elsewhere". It's not clear whether "license" here is equated with confirming that CGTN falls under the jurisdiction of France and hence is able to broadcast in France. If it did mean the same thing, it would match the view in the FT article. If it doesn't, I don't know what else it can refer to.  Also, it's curious to note that the term "licence" was only used in the Financial Times article to refer to the UK license that was stripped from CGTN, and not at all in relation to a potential French license.

Well. I’m not going spout a conspiracy theory but I can think of something dreadfully evil that could transpire if this happens. Of course at the end of the day what will the optics look like. A twist and turn nobody would expect.

France has no law that prohibits state-controlled broadcasters from airing within the country.
The French media watchdog, Conseil supérieur de l’audiovisuel (CSA), has stated that further analysis is required for a decision  and that id would depend on technical issues rather political ones.
After rejection by OFCOM in the UK of the CGTN broadcast licence, China would benefit from a positive judgement form the CSA as according to the Council of Europe Treaty, if any one member allows it broadcast, then it broadcast to all members. (The Council of Europe has 47 members that include France, UK and China). Brexit does not affect this.
Therefore, CGTN could overcome the OFCOM rejection as being an arm of the Chinese Communist Party lacking editorial independence (that contravenes UK Law), but local operators would have to agree to carry the broadcaster. (Vodaphone in Germany has dropped CGTN from its cable network.)
No matter the outcome, CGTN is still able to stream its content online and keep its European HQ. The French decision may be swayed by trade implications and previous agreements made by France and China. For example, France is allowing Huawei to invest in its 5G networks which builds on trade deals worth USD15 billion. 
From the EU, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has stated that the bloc is ‘really serious’ about gaining further access to the Chinese market, remembering that EU/China bilateral trade is worth one billion euros per day constituting the EU as China’s top trading partner. For Airbus in France and motor manufacturers in Germany, it makes economic sense to keep China onside.
